channel.title: About on Mae Saslaw
channel.description: Recent content in About on Mae Saslaw

item.title: Presentations
item.description: Gregory Henkes, ​Mae Saslaw, and Craig Feibel. Persistent warmth in the Turkana Basin, Kenya, from the Late Miocene until present day. 2020. abstract Kevin Hatton, Troy Rasbury, Gregory Henkes, Mae Saslaw,​ Katie Wooton, Francis Sousa, Stephen Cox, Elena Steponaitis, Sidney R Hemming, Susanne Cote, Paul Northrup, Isaiah Nengo, Theodore Present, Patricia Princehouse, James B Rossie and Ryan Tappero. U-Pb Dating of Oligocene-Miocene Petrified Wood Carbonates from the Turkana Basin, Kenya. 2020.

item.title: Testing Rmarkdown with GNIP data
item.description: Viewing data I’ve downloaded a small set of data from the International Atomic Energy Agency Global Network for Isotopes in Precipitation that includes water isotope data collected in the last 10 years from 14 sites around the world. With this data source, I can’t pull directly, but I can convert and load a .csv. The code chunk that produces this table also cleans up the data for display.

item.title: The making of
item.description: (in progress) This is a post about creating a website using Hugo, GitHub, and blogdown for Rmarkdown. There are a number of approaches to this setup, where it starts and which tools to use specifically. My approach is based on prior experience with static site generators, markdown, GitHub, and RStudio. Phase One Acceptance I was due for making another work website, and I started with the most obvious option — I made a Wordpress site on my school’s hosting platform.

item.title: Curriculum vitae
item.description: Education Expected 2024: Doctor of Philosophy, Geosciences Stony Brook University Bachelor of Science, Geology Portland State University 2019 Bachelor of Fine Arts, Writing Pratt Institute 2009 Research Graduate Research Assistant, Clumped isotope paleoclimate records from Miocene soil carbonates, Turkana Basin, Kenya Stony Brook University Department of Geosciences Fall 2019 – Present NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates, Stable isotopes of surface water across Sauvie Island, Oregon Portland State University Center for Climate and Aerosol Research
